slides.title: Welcome to Inorganic Chemistry
slides.content:
# Introduction to Inorganic Chemistry

Welcome to **Inorganic Chemistry** - the study of all elements and their compounds!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Periodic Table Trends** - Patterns across elements
- **Acids and Bases** - Proton donors and acceptors
- **Redox Reactions** - Electron transfer processes
- **Coordination Compounds** - Metal complexes

> **Fun Fact:** Inorganic chemistry covers about 95% of all known compounds!

## Why Inorganic Chemistry Matters:
- Catalysts for industrial processes
- Medicines and medical imaging
- Electronics and semiconductors
- Environmental chemistry

## Elements Overview:

| Category | Examples | Properties |
|----------|----------|------------|
| Metals | Na, Fe, Cu | Shiny, conductive |
| Non-metals | O, N, Cl | Varied, often gases |
| Metalloids | Si, Ge | Properties of both |
| Noble gases | He, Ne, Ar | Unreactive |

slides.title: Periodic Table Organization
slides.content:
# Periodic Table Organization

The **periodic table** organizes elements by atomic number and properties.

## Structure:

### Periods (Rows 1-7):
- Same number of electron shells
- Properties change across period

### Groups (Columns 1-18):
- Same number of valence electrons
- Similar chemical properties

## Important Groups:

| Group | Name | Valence e- |
|-------|------|------------|
| 1 | Alkali metals | 1 |
| 2 | Alkaline earth | 2 |
| 17 | Halogens | 7 |
| 18 | Noble gases | 8 |

## Blocks:

| Block | Elements | Filling Orbital |
|-------|----------|----------------|
| s-block | Groups 1-2 | s orbital |
| p-block | Groups 13-18 | p orbital |
| d-block | Groups 3-12 | d orbital |
| f-block | Lanthanides, Actinides | f orbital |

> **Mendeleev's brilliance:** He left gaps for undiscovered elements and predicted their properties!

slides.title: Periodic Trends
slides.content:
# Periodic Trends

## Atomic Radius:

### Across Period (Left to Right): **DECREASES**
- More protons = stronger pull on same shell electrons

### Down Group (Top to Bottom): **INCREASES**
- More electron shells added

## Electronegativity:

**Electronegativity** = ability to attract electrons in a bond.

- **Increases** across a period
- **Decreases** down a group
- Highest: Fluorine (4.0)

## Ionization Energy:

**Ionization energy** = energy to remove an electron.

- **Increases** across a period
- **Decreases** down a group

## Summary Table:

| Property | Across Period | Down Group |
|----------|--------------|------------|
| Atomic radius | Decreases | Increases |
| Ionization energy | Increases | Decreases |
| Electronegativity | Increases | Decreases |

## Ionic Radius:

- **Cations:** Smaller than parent atom
- **Anions:** Larger than parent atom

slides.title: Acids and Bases
slides.content:
# Acids and Bases

## Definitions:

### Arrhenius:
- **Acid:** Produces H+ in water
- **Base:** Produces OH- in water

### Bronsted-Lowry:
- **Acid:** Proton (H+) donor
- **Base:** Proton (H+) acceptor

## pH Scale:

```
pH = -log[H+]
```

| pH | Nature |
|-----|--------|
| 0-6 | Acidic |
| 7 | Neutral |
| 8-14 | Basic |

## Strong vs Weak:

| Type | Ionization | Examples |
|------|------------|----------|
| Strong acid | 100% | HCl, HNO3, H2SO4 |
| Weak acid | Partial | CH3COOH, HF |
| Strong base | 100% | NaOH, KOH |
| Weak base | Partial | NH3 |

## Neutralization:

```
Acid + Base -> Salt + Water
HCl + NaOH -> NaCl + H2O
```

slides.title: pH Calculations
slides.content:
# pH Calculations

## Key Equations:

```
pH = -log[H+]
pOH = -log[OH-]
pH + pOH = 14
```

## Common pH Values:

| Substance | pH |
|-----------|-----|
| Stomach acid | 1-2 |
| Lemon juice | 2.4 |
| Pure water | 7.0 |
| Blood | 7.4 |
| Bleach | 12.5 |

## Example Calculations:

**Find pH:** [H+] = 0.001 M
```
pH = -log(0.001) = 3
```

**Find [H+]:** pH = 5
```
[H+] = 10^-5 M
```

## Buffers:

Resist pH change when acid/base added.

**Components:** Weak acid + conjugate base

**Henderson-Hasselbalch:**
```
pH = pKa + log([A-]/[HA])
```

> **Blood buffer:** H2CO3/HCO3- maintains blood pH at 7.4

slides.title: Redox Reactions
slides.content:
# Redox Reactions

**Redox** = electron transfer reactions.

## Definitions:

### Oxidation:
- LOSS of electrons
- Oxidation state INCREASES
- **OIL:** Oxidation Is Loss

### Reduction:
- GAIN of electrons
- Oxidation state DECREASES
- **RIG:** Reduction Is Gain

## Oxidation States Rules:

| Rule | State |
|------|-------|
| Element | 0 |
| Monatomic ion | Charge |
| H (usually) | +1 |
| O (usually) | -2 |
| Sum in compound | 0 |

## Example: Mg + Cl2 -> MgCl2

```
Mg: 0 -> +2 (oxidized)
Cl: 0 -> -1 (reduced)
```

## Agents:

| Agent | Does What | Happens to It |
|-------|-----------|---------------|
| Oxidizing | Causes oxidation | Gets reduced |
| Reducing | Causes reduction | Gets oxidized |

slides.title: Electrochemistry
slides.content:
# Electrochemistry

## Galvanic (Voltaic) Cells:

Convert chemical energy to electrical energy.

### Components:
- **Anode:** Oxidation occurs (- terminal)
- **Cathode:** Reduction occurs (+ terminal)
- **Salt bridge:** Maintains neutrality

## Cell Potential:

```
E_cell = E_cathode - E_anode
```

Positive E_cell = spontaneous

## Standard Reduction Potentials:

| Half-Reaction | E (V) |
|---------------|-------|
| F2 + 2e- -> 2F- | +2.87 |
| Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu | +0.34 |
| 2H+ + 2e- -> H2 | 0.00 |
| Zn2+ + 2e- -> Zn | -0.76 |

## Electrolytic Cells:

Use electrical energy for non-spontaneous reactions.

| Process | Product |
|---------|--------|
| Electrolysis of water | H2 and O2 |
| Electrolysis of NaCl | Na and Cl2 |
| Electroplating | Metal coating |

slides.title: Coordination Compounds
slides.content:
# Coordination Compounds

**Coordination compounds** = central metal + surrounding ligands.

## Terminology:

- **Central metal:** Transition metal atom/ion
- **Ligands:** Molecules/ions bonded to metal
- **Coordination number:** Bonds to metal

## Common Geometries:

| Coord # | Geometry |
|---------|----------|
| 2 | Linear |
| 4 | Tetrahedral or Square planar |
| 6 | Octahedral |

## Types of Ligands:

| Type | Bonds | Examples |
|------|-------|----------|
| Monodentate | 1 | NH3, Cl-, H2O |
| Bidentate | 2 | ethylenediamine |
| Polydentate | Many | EDTA |

## Common Ligands:

| Ligand | Name in Complex |
|--------|----------------|
| H2O | aqua |
| NH3 | ammine |
| Cl- | chloro |
| CN- | cyano |

slides.title: Crystal Field Theory
slides.content:
# Crystal Field Theory

Explains bonding and properties of coordination compounds.

## d Orbital Splitting:

Ligands cause energy splitting of d orbitals.

### Octahedral Field:
- Higher energy: eg (dx2-y2, dz2)
- Lower energy: t2g (dxy, dxz, dyz)

## Spectrochemical Series:

```
I- < Br- < Cl- < F- < H2O < NH3 < CN- < CO
(weak field)         (strong field)
```

## High Spin vs Low Spin:

| Configuration | Condition |
|---------------|----------|
| High spin | Weak field ligand |
| Low spin | Strong field ligand |

## Color in Complexes:

| Complex | Color |
|---------|-------|
| [Cu(H2O)6]2+ | Blue |
| [Cu(NH3)4]2+ | Deep blue |
| [Fe(SCN)]2+ | Blood red |

> **Why gems are colored:** Transition metal impurities create d-d transitions!

slides.title: Transition Metals
slides.content:
# Transition Metals

**Transition metals** = d-block elements with partially filled d orbitals.

## Properties:

| Property | Explanation |
|----------|-------------|
| High melting points | Strong metallic bonding |
| Colored compounds | d-d transitions |
| Catalytic activity | Variable oxidation states |
| Form complex ions | Available d orbitals |

## Variable Oxidation States:

| Element | States |
|---------|--------|
| Fe | +2, +3 |
| Cu | +1, +2 |
| Mn | +2, +3, +4, +6, +7 |

## Catalysis:

| Metal | Use |
|-------|-----|
| Fe | Haber process (NH3) |
| Pt, Pd | Catalytic converters |
| Ni | Hydrogenation |

## Colored Compounds:

| Compound | Color |
|----------|-------|
| CuSO4.5H2O | Blue |
| Fe2O3 | Red-brown |
| KMnO4 | Purple |

slides.title: Main Group Elements
slides.content:
# Main Group Elements

## Group 1: Alkali Metals

- Very reactive, soft metals
- Form +1 ions
- React vigorously with water

```
2Na + 2H2O -> 2NaOH + H2
```

## Group 2: Alkaline Earth

- Less reactive than alkali metals
- Form +2 ions
- Ca, Mg biologically important

## Group 17: Halogens

| Element | State | Color |
|---------|-------|-------|
| F2 | Gas | Pale yellow |
| Cl2 | Gas | Yellow-green |
| Br2 | Liquid | Red-brown |
| I2 | Solid | Purple-black |

Reactivity **decreases** down group!

## Group 18: Noble Gases

- Full valence shells
- Very unreactive
- Used in lighting, MRI

## Important Compounds:

| Compound | Use |
|----------|-----|
| NaCl | Table salt |
| CaCO3 | Limestone |
| NaHCO3 | Baking soda |

slides.title: Metallurgy
slides.content:
# Metallurgy

**Metallurgy** = extracting metals from ores.

## Steps:

### 1. Concentration:
- Froth flotation
- Gravity separation
- Magnetic separation

### 2. Extraction:

| Method | Metal Type |
|--------|------------|
| Electrolysis | Very reactive (Na, Al) |
| Carbon reduction | Moderate (Fe, Zn) |
| Roasting | Low reactivity (Cu) |

### 3. Refining:
- Electrolytic (high purity)
- Zone refining (ultra-pure)

## Iron Extraction:

```
Fe2O3 + 3CO -> 2Fe + 3CO2
```

## Aluminum Extraction:

- Cannot use carbon (too reactive)
- Electrolysis of Al2O3 in cryolite
- Very energy intensive

> **Recycling:** Aluminum from cans uses only 5% of energy needed from ore!

slides.title: Environmental Chemistry
slides.content:
# Environmental Inorganic Chemistry

## Ozone Layer:

```
Formation: 3O2 -> 2O3 (UV)
Depletion: O3 + Cl -> ClO + O2
```

CFCs damage ozone layer.

## Acid Rain:

```
SO2 + H2O -> H2SO3
NO2 + H2O -> HNO3
```

## Heavy Metal Pollution:

| Metal | Source | Effect |
|-------|--------|--------|
| Pb | Paint, pipes | Neurological |
| Hg | Industry | Brain damage |
| Cd | Batteries | Kidney damage |

## Water Treatment:

- Al2(SO4)3 as coagulant
- Cl2 for disinfection
- Ca(OH)2 for pH adjustment

## Catalytic Converters:

```
2CO + O2 -> 2CO2
2NO -> N2 + O2
```

Use Pt, Pd, Rh catalysts.

> **Success:** Montreal Protocol banned CFCs, ozone layer now recovering!

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Inorganic Chemistry Summary

## Periodic Trends:

| Property | Across Period | Down Group |
|----------|--------------|------------|
| Atomic radius | Decreases | Increases |
| IE | Increases | Decreases |
| EN | Increases | Decreases |

## Acids/Bases:
- pH = -log[H+]
- pH + pOH = 14
- Neutralization produces salt + water

## Redox:
- Oxidation = electron loss
- Reduction = electron gain
- E_cell = E_cathode - E_anode

## Coordination Compounds:
- Central metal + ligands
- Crystal field theory explains color
- Spectrochemical series orders ligands

## Key Points:
- Transition metals: variable oxidation states, colored, catalytic
- Main group elements: predictable behavior by group
- Metallurgy: extraction and refining of metals

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Inorganic Chemistry!
